Class State

  • java.lang.Object
    • State

  • public class State
extends java.lang.Object
    Defines an arbitrary state with possible transitions to other states.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      State(java.lang.String id)
      Creates a final state; one that must have no transitions.
      State(java.lang.String id, java.util.Random randomizer)
      Creates a nonfinal state; one that must have transitions.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void addTransition(Transition transition)
      Adds a transition to another state.
      void commit()
      Finalizes the state tree.
      java.lang.String generateDot()
      Generates the Dot output from the tree as defined in the task description.
      java.lang.String getID()
      Returns the state ID.
      java.util.List<java.lang.String> visit()
      Visits this state.

      • Methods inherited from class java.lang.Object

        equals, getClass, hashCode, notify, notifyAll, toString, wait, wait, wait

    • Method Detail

      • addTransition

        public void addTransition(Transition transition)
        Adds a transition to another state. [1]
        Parameters:
        transition - the transition

      • commit

        public void commit()
        Finalizes the state tree. [11] It verifies that the probability from all transitions sum to 1.0 (+/- 0.01).

        Sort the transitions with Collections.sort() in ascending order.

        Recursively call commit() on all states that can be transitioned to.

        Throws:
        java.lang.RuntimeException - is the sum of the transitions is invalid

      • generateDot

        public java.lang.String generateDot()
        Generates the Dot output from the tree as defined in the task description. This is a helper method into the other generateDot(Set). [5]
        Returns:
        the Dot output

      • getID

        public java.lang.String getID()
        Returns the state ID. [1]
        Returns:
        the ID

      • visit

        public java.util.List<java.lang.String> visit()
        Visits this state. [16] Nothing happens upon visitation, but the visit is recorded, which presumably means something happened.

        For nonfinal states, draw a random float from the randomizer given in the constructor. Check against each transition to see if the random number is less than the cumulative thresholds up to this point (which is why they are sorted). If so,

        Returns:
        the IDs of the states visited. They do not need to be in the order of visitation.
